HOW_CONDUCT_WAS_DISCOVERED: In May 2004, Si Chan Wooh, the former Executive Vice President and head of SSI International (Schnitzer Steels Tacoma, WA-based subsidiary which oversaw SSI Korea) disclosed the improper payments to Schnitzer Steel's compliance department, prompting an internal investigation into possible FCPA violations.  At that time, Robert W. Philip, Schnitzer Steels former Chairman and CEO, prohibited any further payments but nonetheless authorized Wooh to pay two additional bribes that the company previously had promised private customers in South Korea.  Philip also authorized increased entertainment expenses in lieu of cash payments to its private and government-owned scrap metal customers.  As a result, Schnitzer Steel employees gave managers of the company's scrap metal customers additional gifts, including gift certificates worth $10,000 and a watch worth $2,400.After the internal investigation began, but before Schnitzer Steel had issued a directive to its employees to preserve documents related to the scrap metal transactions, Wooh authorized SSI Korea employees to destroy documents concerning the improper payments.During the period of the conduct, Schnitzer Steel provided no training or education to any of its employees, agents or subsidiaries regarding the requirements of the FCPA, nor had the company established a program to monitor its employees, agents and subsidiaries for compliance with the FCPA.Schnitzer Steel self-disclosed to the DOJ and SEC.

From 1996 through 1998, ABNH and Joshua Cantor, the former president and director of ABNH (and the former executive vice president of ABNH's parent, American Banknote Corporation ("ABN"), were involved in a scheme to fraudulently inflate the revenues and net income of ABNH and ABN in order to meet the earnings forecasts and condition the market for ABNH's initial public offering. In 1998, ABNH and Cantor violated the anti-bribery and books and records and internal controls provisions of the FCPA by making USD 239,000 in improper payments to one or more government officials in Saudi Arabia.  One of ABNH's sales agents had informed an ABNH employee of an opportunity to bid on a contract to produce holograms for a commemorative banknote for the Saudi Arabian Monetary Agency (SAMA).  In an effort to win the contract, Cantor, with the authorization of a senior officer and at his direction, authorized and directed an ABNH employee to wire USD 239,000 to a Swiss bank account for the benefit of the Director of the Issues and Vaults Department of SAMA and possibly other Saudi government officials.  The money was wired and ABNH accounted for this payment as a consulting fee.  This USD 239,000 payment comprised nearly 40% of the value of the contract being sought.  SAMA awarded the contract to ABNH, which subsequently supplied approximately 105 million holograms in connection with the commemorative banknote project.

Avery's Asia Pacific Group discovered the kickback arrangement with the Wuxi Institute in September 2004, after which Avery conducted an internal review of the Reflectives Division and another division of Avery China.  Avery self-disclosed the possible improper payments to the SEC in 2005.  After making its voluntary disclosure, Avery discovered the additional instances of improper payments made by the acquired companies in Indonesia, Pakistan and China.  The improper payments made by Paxar Indonesia were uncovered through a whistleblower; Paxar Pakistans payments were uncovered during an internal audit review; and the payments made by Paxar China were uncovered during the course of a global trade compliance review that included in-depth FCPA reviews in ten high risk countries.

The improper conduct was discovered after an ex-employee filed suit against Baker Hughes in 2002 alleging that he lost his job because he refused to go along with a bribery scheme in Nigeria.  The filing of this suit prompted Baker Hughes' board to hire outside counsel to conduct an investigation into the charges, which ultimately lasted for five years and unearthed several violations in multiple countries.   Baker Hughes self-disclosed the violations the SEC and DOJ.  According to the DOJ, Baker Hughes conducted an extensive and thorough internal investigation of its business practices in Kazakhstan and throughout its high-risk global operations and has implemented significant remedial steps and improvements to its controls.

According to the SEC's complaint, between September 1997 and August 2000, former senior management of BellSouth's Venezuelan subsidiary, TelCel, authorized payments totaling approximately USD 10.8 million to six offshore companies.  These payments were then improperly recorded as bona fide disbursements in Telcel's books and records, based on fictitious invoices.  Telcel's internal controls failed to detect the payments for at least two years and BellSouth was unable to reconstruct the circumstances or purpose of the Telcel payments, or identify their ultimate recipients.  The SEC noted that Telcel was Venezuela's leading wireless provider at the time and contributed more revenue to BellSouth's Latin American Group segment than any of its other Latin American operations.  The SEC also alleged that BellSouth's Nicaraguan subsidiary, Telefonia, improperly recorded payments made to the wife of the Nicaraguan legislator who chaired the Nicaraguan legislative committee overseeing telecommunications in the country.  BellSouth had acquired a 49% interest in Telefonia in 1997 with an option to acquire an additional 40%.  BellSouth's subsidiary, BSI, obtained operating control of the company and its board.  BellSouth sought to exercise its 40% option but could only do so if Nicaragua repealed its law prohibiting majority foreign ownership in local telecommunications companies.  In October 1998, Telefonia retained the legislator's wife (who had prior financial and operations experience in the telecommunications area, but no prior legislative experience) as a lobbyist for the repeal of the foreign ownership restriction.In May 1999, Telefonia terminated the lobbyist and in June 1999 paid her a severance of USD 60,000, recording the sum as consulting services and a severance payment.  The legislative amendment to repeal the foreign ownership restriction was referred to the Nicaraguan National Assembly in September and was passed in December 1999.  BellSouth increased its ownership in Telefonia to 89% in June 2000.

In June 2002, in the course of investigating the possible unauthorized use of funds in Argentina by BJ Services and BJSA personnel, senior management at BJ Services learned that FCPA violations may have occurred in the country.  BJ Services began an internal investigation into these payments and their accounting, engaging outside counsel in both the U.S. and Argentina.  BJ Services disclosed the matter to its outside auditors and its full board of directors.  Upon completion of the internal investigation, BJ Services made a voluntary disclosure to the SEC.  The company informed the SEC of the results of the internal investigation and cooperated with the SEC's investigation, including waiving its attorney-client privilege over communications during the relevant time period.

Bristow's internal investigation started following an October 2004 company management meeting at which its newly-appointed CEO heard a comment suggesting that payments may had been made to government officials in Nigeria.  The CEO reported it immediately to the audit committee and contacted outside counsel.  The audit committee hired independent counsel, which conducted the internal investigation.  Bristow Group then self-disclosed the violations to the SEC and instituted measures to improve its compliance program.

The SEC acknowledged that Chiquita's policies and procedures contain strict guidelines regarding the use of discretionary expenses accounts.  In 1996, Chiquita's internal auditing staff notified management of a number of instances where Banadex had failed to provide documentation regarding discretionary expenses, as required by Chiquita's internal accounting control procedures.  Chiquita had strict policies prohibiting improper payments to customs officials and the company monitored and enforced those policies by requiring the quarterly identification and disclosure of all payments to government officials or employees, political candidates, or political parties. In contravention of Chiquita policy, Banadex failed to identify and disclose the USD 30,000 in payments on the disclosure forms submitted for the relevant quarters.  In April 1997, Chiquita's internal audit staff uncovered the payments during an audit review of Banadex.  Chiquita conducted an internal investigation and took corrective action, including terminating the responsible Banadex employees and reinforcing its internal controls with respect to its Colombian operations.  Chiquita voluntarily disclosed the matter to the SEC.

The DOJ charged CSS and Crites with conspiracy to violate the FCPA, substantive violations of the FCPA, and bribery of a U.S. public official in connection with improper payments made to a Lieutenant Colonel in the Brazilian Air Force (the BAF Lt. Col.) between 1995-1996 in order to secure sales of surplus military equipment to the Brazilian Aeronautical Commission ("BAC").  According to the Criminal Information, CSS and Crites made the agreement with the BAF Lt. Col. with the assistance of a U.S. Air Force civilian employee serving as the Command Country Manager for Brazil at the Wright Patterson Air Force in Ohio (the Country Manager).  Under the arrangement, the Country Manager provided Crites with surplus part numbers, model numbers, and U.S. military sources of surplus parts, in exchange for payments of money.  Crites then purchased the surplus equipment identified by the Country Manager, reconditioned it, and resold the same to the BAC.  The BAF Lt. Col. approved the purchases from CSS in exchange for payments of money.  Later, Crites and the Country Manager prepared and submitted bids to the BAC through the BAF Lt. Col., which involved additional improper payments.  Crites subsequently paid the BAF Lt. Col. a series of improper payments, disguised as consultant fees, for each bid accepted.Crites, through CSS and another company listed the Criminal Information as Company Y, arranged at least 44 purchases of surplus U.S. military equipment for repair and resale to the BAC.  Following each purchase, the BAF Lt. Col. was paid for his approval of the transaction.  Between 1994 and 1996, CSS, Crites and other unnamed individuals paid a total of USD 99,000 to the Country Manager and a total of USD 257,139 to the BAF Lt. Col.

Con-way uncovered potential FCPA violations at Emery Transnational in early 2003, after Menlo Forwarding increased Emery Transnational's internal reporting requirements in January 2003, including requiring the company to begin reporting its income and expenses in addition to its net profits.  Menlo Forwarding employees noticed unusually high customs and airline-related expenditures as a result of reviewing Emery Transnationals records.  Menlo Forwarding conducted an internal investigation into the matter and, based on this investigation, Con-way initiated a broader review of all of Menlo Forwarding's foreign businesses.  Con-way voluntarily disclosed the potential FCPA violations to the SEC.  After completing its internal investigation, Con-way imposed enhanced financial reporting and compliance requirements on Emery Transnational.  In addition, Menlo Forwarding terminated a number of Emery Transnational employees involved in the misconduct.  Con-way also strengthened its regulatory compliance program and provided additional FCPA training and education to its employees.

The payments were made without the authorization or knowledge of any Dow employee.  Once Dow discovered the matter, it conducted an internal investigation and voluntarily disclosed its findings to the SEC.  Dow also took a number of remedial actions, including employee terminations and disciplinary actions.The company retained an independent auditor to conduct a forensic audit of the books and records and internal controls at DE-Nocil and reported its internal investigation to the Audit Committee of the Board of Directors.  Dow provided FCPA compliance training to DE-Nocil employees, as well as to employees of its Dow AgroSciences business unit more broadly.  Dow also restructured its global compliance program, including (i) improving and expanding FCPA compliance training for employees of Dow and its subsidiaries worldwide; (ii) training its internal auditors to recognize FCPA issues; and (iii) joining a non-profit association specializing in anti-bribery due diligence that, among other things, screens potential partners and other third parties that work with multinational corporations and provides FCPA training to them.  In addition, the company hired an independent consultant to review and assess its FCPA compliance program.

The Greens were arrested on 18 December 2007 on charges of conspiring to pay more than USD 1.7 million in bribes to former TAT governor Siriwan in return for the contracts to administer the annual Bangkok International Film Festival.  On 1 October 2008, the grand jury returned a superseding indictment adding new charges alleging bribery of Siriwan in exchange for the elite privilege card contracts, as well as money laundering charges and allegations that Mrs. Green knowingly subscribed two false U.S. corporate income tax returns.

According to press reports, the TSKJ bribery scheme in Nigeria came to light during the course of investigations by French prosecutors into Elf-Aquitane's operations in Asia and Africa. During those investigations, Georges Krammer, former director general of Technip, was accused of paying EUR 3 million in illegal commissions.  Although disputed by Technip management, Krammer claimed that the commissions were legal and in line with company policy.  Facing charges of misappropriation, Krammer went before a French judge and disclosed how Technip's commission payment system worked in Indonesia, Thailand and on the LNG Project in Nigeria.  This prompted a French investigation into the Nigeria LNG bribery scandal, which then triggered investigations by the United States, Switzerland, and Nigeria.

In early 2008, H&P; designed and implemented a stand-alone set of FCPA policies and procedures as part of an effort to improve the company's compliance with the FCPA.  In connection with this effort, the company also designed and conducted worldwide FCPA training for its key employees.  During a training session in May 2008, an employee disclosed that potentially improper payments had been made by H&P; Argentina to Argentina customs officials through a customs broker.  The information was transmitted to the H&P;'s corporate headquarters and came to the attention of the general counsel in July 2008.  In response, H&P; retained outside FCPA counsel and independent forensic accountants to conduct an internal investigation into the customs payment practices of H&P;'s subsidiaries in various Latin American countries.  H&P;'s internal investigation identified fifty improper payments made to government customs officials in Argentina and Venezuela from 2003 through 2008, totaling approximately USD 185,673.  In October 2008, H&P; voluntarily disclosed its initial findings to the DOJ and SEC.
Hioki was one of eight foreign executive arrested on 2 May 2007 in Houston and San Francisco and charged for their roles in the marine hose cartel, after participating in a cartel meeting in Houston.

Argentine authorities began investigating the BNA transaction after a routine tax audit uncovered evidence that some of the money IBM-Argentina paid to CCR had been passed on to phantom companies.  Fifteen BNA directors and IBM-Argentina executives were indicted for bribery in Argentina and the Argentine judge overseeing the investigation issued an international arrest warrant, through Interpol, for four U.S. IBM executives (the warrants were later withdrawn).  Bribery investigations were also opened into five additional IBM-Argentina public contracts, along with an investigation into possible tax evasion (through the claiming of the alleged bribes as deductible expenses).  After learning of the investigations launched in Argentina, IBM launched an internal investigation.  According to the SEC, after IBM learned that its policies and procedures had been circumvented by IBM-Argentina's former senior management, the company took immediate corrective action.  Among other things, IBM-Argentina's Vice President of Operations was terminated, and the General Manager and Vice President of Finance were both asked to resign from their positions, which they did.  In addition, all future payments to CCR under the subcontract were stopped and IBM enhanced its internal controls with respect to FCPA compliance.

During 1994, M&E; bid on, and was awarded, a U.S. Agency for International Development ("USAID") contract to provide support for the maintenance of wastewater treatment facilities managed by the Alexandria General Organization for Sanitary Drainage ("AGOSD"), the government agency responsible for sewage and wastewater treatment facilities in Alexandria, Egypt.  The contract lasted from November 1994 until May 1997.  In 1995, M&E; bid on a second USAID contract to provide architectural and engineering services to AGOSD, which lasted from August 1995 until June 1997.  The contracts were awarded by USAID and were reviewed by a Technical Review Board with five voting members.  AGOSD had one voting position and participated in the evaluation and scoring of bidders.  The Chairman of AGOSD did not participate in the evaluation and scoring process, but he could exert influence over AGOSD's representatives on the Technical Review Board.  He could also influence USAID's decision by making his preference for certain companies known. In 1994, M&E; paid for the Chairman of AGOSD and his wife and children to travel to Boston, Massachusetts; Washington, DC; Chicago, Illinois; and Orlando, Florida.  The purpose of the trip was for the Chairman of AGOSD to attend a water conference in Chicago.  In 1996, M&E; paid for a second trip for the Chairman and his family to visit Paris, France; Boston, Massachusetts; and San Diego, California.  On both trips, M&E; provided the Chairman with 150% of his estimated per diem expenses before he left Egypt.  In addition, M&E; paid for the majority of the Chairman and his family's travel and entertainment expenses during the course of both trips.  M&E; also paid to upgrade the Chairman to first class on both trips, and paid to upgrade his family to first class on the second trip.  An officer of M&E; received two undocumented cash advances prior to the 1996 trip, which was used to pay for expenses connected to the Chairman's trip.  M&E; inaccurately recorded expenses related to these trips in its books and records. While in the United States in 1994, the Chairman signed an order on behalf of AGOSD recommending M&E; for the first contract.  Two months before the second trip, an M&E; employee wrote to the Chairman expressing the company's interest in continuing its contract on the project and requesting AGOSD's support through the Chairman's contacts at USAID and in the Egyptian government.  Shortly after the second trip, the Chairman sent a letter to USAID requesting an extension of the first contract.

In early 1972, Wallce E. Carroll, Katy's Chairman and CEO, sought to obtain an oil exploration concession in Indonesia.  As a result, a Katy director and a Katy consultant, who were close personal friends with a high level Indonesian government official, met with this official and one of his representatives.  At that meeting, the official agreed to assist Katy in obtaining an oil production sharing contract.  Katy agreed to compensate the consultant upon receipt of the contract, understanding that the consultant would give a portion of his compensation to the official and his representative.   From September 1972 to March 1974, Katy paid the consultant at least USD 43,750 in consulting fees.  Katy also retained the official's representative as an agent for Katy and paid him at least USD 22,500 between December 1972 and September 1973, in addition to reimbursing him for out-of-pocket expenses incurred on behalf of Katy.In January 1974, Katy entered into a 30-year production-sharing contract with Pertamina, the Indonesian government-owned oil and gas company, granting Katy the exclusive right to explore and develop oil and natural gas within a designated area of Indonesia.  According to the complaint, the total cost of this contract was USD 10,000,000.  Between January 1974 and April 1975, Jacobs and Carroll negotiated agreements setting forth the plan to compensate the official, the official's representative and the consultant through an offshore corporation in the Cayman Islands to be created by the consultant.  Katy agreed to pay the offshore corporation 13.33% of Katy-Indonesia's annual net profits arising from the contract, for the benefit of the official, his representative and the consultant.  Between March and April 1975, Katy paid the consultant USD 50,000 as an advance on payments to be made to the offshore corporation.  Additional advances totaling USD 200,000 were paid in four installments between September 1975 and May 1976, to be applied against the 13.33% share.  No payments were made pursuant to the agreement after May 1976, but the contractual obligation continued through July 1978 at which time Katy terminated the agreement with the offshore corporation.Throughout the period discussed above, Katy, Carroll and Jacobs made a series of misrepresentations to shareholders and investors regarding the production-sharing contract.  According to Katy, a single find of a major field in the region would be worth USD 108,000,000.  According to the complaint, exploration of the area covered by the contract ceased pending the resolution of certain tax problems, but was anticipated to resume before the end of 1978.

Sometime in 1995, Thomas Qualey, President of IMS, met with a Lieutenant Colonel in the Brazilian Air Force who was stationed as a Foreign Liaison Officer at the Wright Patterson Air Force Base in Ohio.   The Lt. Col. was authorized to make purchases of military equipment on behalf of the purchasing agent of the Brazilian Air Force, the Brazilian Aeronautical Commission ("BAC").  Sometime in 1995, the Lt. Col. and Thomas Qualey agreed that IMS would purchase fork lift trucks, recondition them and then resell them to the BAC.   The Lt. Col. would approve the BAC's purchases in exchange for payments from IMS.  Between 1995 and 1996, Thomas Qualey arranged two purchases of fork lifts for repair and resale.  After each purchase, the Lt. Col. was paid by IMS for his approval of the transaction.  IMS paid the Lt. Col. USD 42,950 for the first transaction, and received USD 229,000 in revenue from the BAC.  IMS paid the Lt. Col. USD 24,613 for the second transaction, and received USD 163,250 in revenue.  IMS falsely described the payments to the Lt. Col. as sales commissions.

Immediately following the companies settlement with the DOJ on 6 December 2004, GE completed its USD 900 million acquisition of InVision.

In Spring 2009, the DOJ charged Juan Diaz, President of J.D. Locator Services, a Miami-based shell intermediary for three private telecommunications companies and Antonio Perez, former Controller at Terra Telecommunications Corp., a Miami-based telecommunications company, with conspiracy to violate the FCPA and money laundering laws in connection with over $1 million in improper payments made to former Haitian government officials.  [While court documents do not specifically identify Terra as one of the companies at issue, the company's identity was reported in the press.]Diaz was charged with conspiring to make corrupt payments to Haitian officials for the purpose of securing business advantages from Haiti's state-owned telecommunications company, Telecommunications D'Haiti ("Haiti Teleco"), on behalf of three different Miami-based telecommunications companies, including Terra.  He paid, and concealed payments of, over $1,028,851 to Haitian officials in his capacity as an intermediary for the three companies.  Diaz earned $73,824 in commissions for laundering the bribes.Perez was charged with conspiring to make corrupt payments to officials of Haiti Teleco on behalf of Terra.  He was Controller at the company from March 1998 through January 2002 and assisted the company in making improper payments to former Haitian officials, which totaled approximately $674,193 through the course of the conspiracy, which spanned from 1998 to 2005.  Perez assisted in paying $36,375 worth of side payments from November 2001 through January 2002 and helped conceal the payments through Diaz's shell company and by recording them as consulting services.  According to court documents, Terra and two other Miami-based telecommunications companies executed a series of contracts with Haiti Teleco so that the company's customers could place telephone calls to Haiti.  Diaz and Perez conspired with the companies to make side payments to the Director of International Relations and the Director General at Haiti Teleco at the time.  The side payments were made through a shell company owned by Diaz.  In exchange for the improper payments, the former Haitian officials provided the Miami-based telecommunications companies with a variety of business advantages, including preferential connection rates and various credits towards sums owed, such as reductions in the number of minutes for which payments were due.   In an indictment unsealed on December 7, 2009, five additional individuals were charged for their alleged roles in the foreign bribery, wire fraud and money laundering scheme, under which, between November 2001 and March 2005, Terra allegedly paid more than $800,000 to shell companies to be used for bribes to foreign officials of Haiti Teleco.Joel Esquenazi, President of Terra, and Carlos Rodriguez, former Executive Vice President at Terra, were indicted for conspiracy to violate the FCPA, conspiracy to commit wire fraud, substantive violations of the FCPA, conspiracy to commit money laundering and substantive counts of money laundering.  Robert Antoine and Jean Rene Duperval, two former Directors of International Relations at Haiti Teleco were charged with conspiracy to commit money laundering and conspiracy and substantive counts of money laundering, respectively.  Marguerite Grandison, President of Telecom Consulting Services Corp., an intermediary for a Miami-based telecommunications company (and Duperval's sister) was charged with conspiracy to violate the FCPA and commit wire fraud, substantive violations of the FCPA, conspiracy to commit money laundering and substantive counts of money laundering.  On February 1, 2010, a criminal information was filed against Jean Fourcand, President and Director of Miami-based Fourcand Enterprises Inc., alleging that, between November 2001 and August 2002, Fourcand received funds originating from U.S. telecommunications companies for the benefit of Haiti Teleco official Robert Antoine.  Various U.S. telecommunications companies sent money to Diaz, who then dispersed the funds by issuing J.D. Locator checks made payable to Fourcand Enterprises.   In one instance, Fourcand received a $18,500 check on February 20, 2002, drawn on J.D. Locator Service‰Ûªs bank account, which Fourcand deposited into a Fourcand Enterprises account.  The check contained a false invoice number to make the payment appear to be for legitimate services.  Fourcand then used the funds to facilitate a real estate transaction for the benefit of Robert Antoine. On July 13, 2011, a superseding indictment was filed in connection with the Haiti Teleco-related foreign bribery, wire fraud and money laundering scheme.  Cinergy Telecommunications Inc., a privately-held Florida telecommunications company, was charged with one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA and to commit wire fraud, six counts of FCPA violations, one count of conspiracy to commit money laundering and 19 counts of money laundering.  Washington Vasconez Cruz, the President of Cinergy and another Florida telecommunications company, Uniplex Telecommunications Inc., was charged with one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA and to commit wire fraud, six counts of FCPA violations, one count of conspiracy to commit money laundering and 19 counts of money laundering.  Amadeus Richers, the then-director of Cinergy and Uniplex, was charged with one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA and to commit wire fraud, six counts of FCPA violations, one count of conspiracy to commit money laundering and 19 counts of money laundering.  Patrick Joseph, a former General Director for Telecommunications at Haiti Teleco, was charged with one count of conspiracy to commit money laundering.  Jean Rene Duperval and Marguerite Grandison, who were previously charged in the initial December 2009 indictment, were each charged with two counts of conspiracy to commit money laundering and 19 counts of money laundering.  The DOJ described the alleged misconduct at issue in the superseding indictment as follows in its July 13, 2011 press release:"According to the superseding indictment, the defendants allegedly participated in a scheme to commit foreign bribery and money laundering from December 2001 through January 2006.   The indictment alleges that during this time period Cinergy and its related company, Uniplex Telecommunications Inc., allegedly paid more than $1.4 million to shell companies to be used for bribes to foreign officials of the Republic of Haiti‰Ûªs state-owned national telecommunications company, Telecommunications D‰ÛªHaiti (Haiti Teleco).According to court documents, Cinergy and Uniplex executed a series of contracts with Haiti Teleco that allowed the companies‰Ûª customers to place telephone calls to Haiti.   The bribe payments allegedly were authorized by Washington Vasconez Cruz, the telecommunications companies‰Ûª president, and Amadeus Richers, the companies‰Ûª director, and were allegedly paid to Haitian government officials at Haiti Teleco, including Patrick Joseph and Jean Rene Duperval.   According to the superseding indictment, the purpose of these bribes was to obtain various business advantages from the Haitian officials for Cinergy and Uniplex, including preferred telecommunications rates and credits toward sums owed.  To conceal the bribe payments, the defendants allegedly used various shell companies to receive and forward the payments, including J.D. Locator Services, Fourcand Enterprises and Telecom Consulting Services."Esquenazi and Rodriguez were charged in the initial December 2009 indictment and are unaffected by the July 2011 superseding indictment.  A second superseding indictment was filed on 20 January 2012, against Cecilia Zurita, who had served as vice president of Cinergy and is married to  Vasconez Cruz.  Zurita is accused of writing checks to shell companies in order for the funds to be used to bribe Haitian officials.  The indictment alleges that over $2.9 million is subject to forfeiture. Media reports dated 4 March 2012 allege that Company A as named in the indictment is Digitek, a suspected front owned by Lesly Lavelanet, the brother-in-law of former president Jean-Bertrand Aristide.  Official B as named in the indictment is said to be Aristide himself, while Venel Joseph (Patrick Joseph's father), who was governor of the Bank of Haiti and appointed by Jean-Bertrand Aristide, is presumed to be named in the indictment as Official A.

He authorized the payment to be made through Immucor Germany in order to assist the hospital director in avoiding Italian taxes.The SEC charged that Immucor violated and that Di Chirico violated and aided and abetted Immucor's violations of  the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions in connection with this conduct.

From 1999 until 2002, the manager of Schering-Plough Poland's oncology unit allegedly made a series of payments totaling approximately USD 76,000 to the Chudow Castle Foundation ("the Foundation").  These payments were allegedly made at the request of the Director of Silesian Health Fund, one of 16 regional government health authorities in Poland, who founded and served as president of the Foundation.  According the SEC complaint, the Schering-Plough Poland manager arranged a total of 13 payments, some of which were structured to be below the manager's approval level.  In addition, the manager provided false justifications for the donations on documents he submitted to Schering-Plough's finance department, including describing the payments as covering fight against viral hepatitis, financing screening examinations to detect skin cancer, and support actions of Foundation in preventing infectious diseases of the liver.  In fact, the Foundations mission was to restore castles and other historic sites in Silesia and it did not provide health care services or medical treatments.  In addition, the SEC stated that while these payments were classified as donations on the Company's books and records, they were really dues that were required in order to obtain the Director's assistance. According to the SEC, Schering-Plough Poland made more payments to the Foundation than to any other organizations during the time period in question.  At the same time, the Company noticed a substantial increase in sales of two of its oncology products, Intron A and Temodal.  By 2002, 53 percent of Intron A and 40 percent of Temodal sales in Poland were in Silesia. The SEC noted that Schering-Plough's policies and procedures did not require due diligence on organizations prior to making charitable contributions.  In addition, the SEC stated that Schering-Plough should have known that there were potential FCPA issues with payments to the Foundation because: (i) the Foundation is not a healthcare related entity; (ii) the amount of payments to the Foundation in relation to Schering-Plough's budget for donations; (iii) the structuring of the payments, which allowed the manager to exceed his spending allowance; and  (iv) the Director was both the founder of the foundation and a Polish government official.

On 7 August 2008, Ousama M. Naaman, a Lebanese and Canadian citizen, was indicted in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia in connection with his alleged role in an eight-year conspiracy to defraud the United Nations ("U.N.") Oil for Food Program and to bribe Iraqi government officials in order to secure sales of a chemical additive used in refining leaded fuel (known as tetraethyl lead). The indictment charged Naaman with one count of conspiracy to commit wire fraud and violate the FCPA and two counts of violating the FCPA's anti-bribery provisions.  According to the indictment, from 2001 to 2003, while acting on behalf of a publicly-traded U.S. chemical company with executive offices in the United Kingdom - understood to be Innospec Inc. - and its Swiss subsidiary, Naaman offered and paid 10% kickbacks to the Iraqi government in order to obtain five contracts under the Oil for Food Program.  In exchange for negotiating and handling the kickbacks, Naaman allegedly received a 2% commission for securing the contract as well as 2% of the contracts value.  The contracts submitted to the U.N. were allegedly inflated by the Innospec in order to cover the cost of the kickbacks.  According to the indictment, Naaman also paid USD 150,000 in bribes to Iraqi Ministry of Oil officials in 2006 on behalf of Innospec to ensure that a competitors product failed a field test and stayed out of the Iraqi market.  Naaman was allegedly reimbursed by Innospec for these improper payments after submitting false invoices. On 24 June 2010, a superseding criminal information replaced the initial indictment.  The new information charged Naaman with orchestrating the arrangement whereby Innospec paid a 10% kickback to the Iraqi government between 2001 and 2003 to obtain five contracts under the Oil-for-Food program to supply tetraethyl lead to Iraq's oil refineries.  Naaman was also charged with paying or promising to pay over USD 3 million in bribes (in the form of cash, travel, gifts and entertainment) between 2004 and 2008 to officials of the Iraqi Ministry of Oil and the Trade Bank of Iraq on Innospec's behalf in order to secure sales of tetraethyl lead and to secure more favorable exchange rates, respectively.

Tesoro allegedly knew that this course of business posed a material risk to the company and failed to make timely and adequate disclosure of the course of business, the unaccountability of such payments, and the particular risks that such course of business posed to material assets and revenues of the company.  The conduct at issue took place prior to the enactment of the FCPA in 1977, which added paragraphs (b)(2) through (b)(5) to Section 13 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, covering the recordkeeping and internal controls provisions of the FCPA.

According to the SEC, from 1996 until 2002, Tyco violated a number of federal securities laws including the books and records provisions of the FCPA.  During that period, Tyco acquired hundred of companies around the world in order to become a large, diversified manufacturing company involved in businesses such as fire protection and security systems, electrical and electronic components, healthcare and engineered products and services.  Included in the SEC complaint were charges that, from 1999 until 2002, two Tyco subsidiaries violated the FCPA.  Specifically, the complaint alleged that in 1998 Tyco acquired Multiservice Engenharia Ltda., which would become Earth Tech Brazil, despite the fact that pre-merger due diligence uncovered that improper payments to government officials were common in Brazil and were described as necessary in the industries in which Earth Tech Brazil operated.  After the acquisition, Earth Tech Brazil made numerous payments to various Brazilian officials in order to assist with its construction and operation of municipal water and wastewater treatment systems.  According to the SEC complaint, the payments were so widespread that 60% of Earth Tech Brazil's contracts during the relevant time period involved payments to government officials.  These payments were made through lobbyists retained for this purpose and false invoices from companies owned by Earth Tech Brazil employees were used to obtain the funds and conceal the payments, causing Tyco to maintain inaccurate books and records. In 1999, Tyco acquired Dong Bang, a fire protection services firm in South Korea.  Again, pre-merger due diligence revealed that improper payments to government officials were prevalent in the South Korean contracting business.  After the acquisition, Dong Bang executives allegedly provided entertainment to South Korean officials and made cash payments.  According to the complaint, Dong Bang's former president spent $32,000 on entertainment provided to various South Korean officials in 2001, and he frequently provided entertainment to South Korea's Minister of Construction and Finance and a South Korean military general in order to obtain business.  In 2002, a Dong Bang Executive paid $7,500 to an employee of a state-owned nuclear power plant in order to obtain a contract.  In order to make the payments, Dong Bang created fictitious employees whose payroll disbursements were wired to the company's executives.  This caused the company to maintain inaccurate books and records. The SEC noted that Tyco did not have an adequate or uniform FCPA compliance program to prevent illegal payments.  In addition, the complaint stated that Earth Tech and Dong Bang employees did not receive adequate training on FCPA compliance given the companys awareness that payments to government officials were prevalent in the industries in which the companies operated. In addition to the FCPA violations, the SEC alleged that Tyco violated federal securities laws by engaging in improper accounting practices in order to inflate its operating income; and failing to disclose certain executive compensation, related party transactions and senior executive indebtedness.

The SEC issued a Report of Investigation in March 2005 to alert companies to potential liability for representations, covenants or other provisions of a merger agreement that are made publicly available.  The SEC made it clear that it considers disclosures of material contractual terms, such as representations, to be actionable. After uncovering the payments during pre-merger due diligence, Titan and Lockheed jointly made a voluntary disclosure to the DOJ and SEC in February 2004.After repeated delays in the Titan's resolution of the matter with the government, Lockheed terminated the merger agreement in June 2004. James Giffen and Mercator, a New York-based merchant bank, represented and advised the Republic of Kazakhstan in connection with the sale of the Kazakh oil fields from 1995 to 1999.  On 4 August 2003, Giffen was indicted for bribing Kazakh officials in violation of the FCPA; defrauding the Republic of Kazakhstan in violation of the mail and wire fraud statutes; money laundering to further and conceal the bribery and fraud; and tax-related offenses.  According to the indictment, Giffen paid more than USD 80 million in bribes to the President of Kazakhstan, Nursultan Nazarbayev, and two other Kazakh officials, making payments into Swiss bank accounts he created in the names of offshore companies owned by those officials or members of their families.  The payments came out of either fees that Giffen and Mercator received in oil deals they brokered for the Republic of Kazakhstan or from escrow accounts holding payments due the Republic from oil transactions.  The bribes were, at times, concealed as loans or as payments of consultancy fees.  The funds in these accounts were allegedly used to pay for the personal expenses of Kazakh officials and their family members, including tuition, jewelry, vacations and credit card bills.  Giffen also allegedly provided a variety of luxury items (including speed boats, snowmobiles, jewelry and fur coats) free of charge to senior Kazakh officials.  Between 1994 and 2000, Mercator received over USD 67 million in commission and fees for its work for the Republic.At trial, Giffen asserted the public authority defense, arguing that he committed the acts based on a grant of authority from the U.S. government, and moved to compel discovery of classified information related to his communications with certain U.S. agencies regarding his activities in Kazakhstan.  The district court denied the government's attempt to preclude Giffen's assertion of the public authority defense and introduction at trial of classified information in support of that defense.  The government appealed to the Second Circuit, which dismissed the appeal for lack of jurisdiction but provided a detailed discussion of the district court's rulings.  J. Bryan Williams was an attorney in Virginia and a former senior executive of Mobil Oil Corporation (now Exxon-Mobil).  He was responsible for Mobil's oil trading operations in the former Soviet Union, including Kazakhstan.  In 1995 and 1996, Williams represented Mobil in negotiations related to the company's acquisition of a 25% interest in Kazazhstan's large Tengiz oil field, as well as other Mobil projects in the country.  As part of the Tengiz deal, Williams received a USD 2 million kickback from Giffen.

Specifically, the indictment alleged that payments were made to a member of the Colombian Camara de Representates ("CDR") in order that telecommunications contracts be awarded to Harris in Columbia.  In addition, payments are alleged to have been made to a company owned by a member of the CDR.   In one instance, it is alleged that a payment of  USD 22,845 was made to Polo with the intention that a portion would be paid to officials.  In another instance, it is alleged that bribe payments were explicitly discussed among the defendants in New York, and Iacobucci declared that he would not travel to Colombia without USD 5,500 in cash. On 9 July 1979, the US Securities and Exchange Commission filed a complaint against International Systems & Controls Corporation and five of its officers and employees, alleging that they violated the FCPA's accounting provisions by making over USD 23 million in improper payments between 1970-1977 to government officials and royal family members in Saudi Arabia, Iran, Algeria, Ivory Coast, Nicaragua, Chile and other countries (reportedly) - through subsidiaries - in order to obtain contracts related to engineering and constructing projects. In July 1989, Morton was trying to negotiate a contract for the sale of buses manufactured by Eagle to the STC, a corporation owned by the government of the Province of Saskatchewan, Canada.  STC operated a bus transportation system in that province.  Morton met with Castle and Lowry, of STC, who told him that in order for Eagle to receive an order for 11 buses a payment of CAD 50,000 would be necessary.  In August 1989, Morton met with Tull and Blondek, of Eagle, at which time Blondek authorized Morton to pay the money demanded by Castle and Lowry.On 15 August 1989, Morton received a check from Lowry in the amount of CAD 52,000 payable to a corporation owned by Morton.  He deposited the check, obtained a bank draft payable to himself and later presented the bank draft at the Royal Bank of Canada in Regina and obtained 50 Canadian CAD 1,000 bills.  On 16 August 1989, Blondek signed a contract for the sale of 11 buses to STC.  The purchase price was approximately USD 2,770,000.Between October and November 1989, Castle and Lowry returned the bills in the CAD 1,000 denomination to Morton and requested that he convert them into bills of CAD 100 denomination, which Morton did.  In order to conceal from STC the check paid to Morton's corporation, Tull directed Morton to prepare a letter on Eagle company letterhead to Ontario Bus Industries, Inc., a Canadian firm which was assisting Eagle in the sale.  The letter falsely stated that STC had been given a volume discount amounting to USD 43,940. The indictment charged Blondek, Tull, Castle and Lowry with conspiring to bribe foreign officials in violation of the FCPA.  Defendants Castle and Lowry moved to dismiss the indictment against them on the grounds that, as Canadian officials, they could not be convicted of the charges.  Blondek and Tull were private U.S. citizens and did not challenge their indictment on this ground.  It was not disputed that Castle and Lowry could not be charged with violating the FCPA, since the Act does not criminalize the receipt of bribes by foreign officials.  The question was whether the Government could prosecute Castle and Lowry under the general conspiracy statute for conspiring to violate the FCPA.

The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (‰ÛÏSEC‰Ûù) charged Ashland Oil and Orin E. ADI began investing in Midland Chrome Mines (Private) Ltd., a company in Zimbabwe owned by Langdon and his family. In 1965, Kenny entered into an agreement with the Government of the Cook Islands (an independent nation freely associated with New Zealand for purposes of external affairs and defense) whereby Kenny obtained the exclusive rights to the promotion, distribution and sale of Cook Islands postage stamps outside of the Cook Islands.  This agreement was renewed in 1972 for a ten-year period.  The Government of the Cook Islands received 50% of the proceeds of all stamps sold.In January 1978, Sir Albert Henry, the Leader of the Cook Islands Party, scheduled a general election for March 1978.  The Cook Islands Party needed to win the majority of seats in the Legislative Assembly if Sir Albert Henry were to remain Premier for the next four-year term.  The stamp distribution agreement between Kenny and the Government of the Cook Islands was subject to renewal during the next Premier's term.  Sir Albert Henry and the party officials determined that to win the election it would be necessary to transport by air from New Zealand Cook Island Party supporters to vote for the Party candidates. A representative of Sir Albert Henry and the Cook Islands Party requested that Kenny and Kenny International subsidize the air transportation costs of the Cook Islands Party supporters.  Kenny, in order to secure the renewal of the stamp distribution agreement, agreed to provide the financial assistance.  The payment was deducted from the Government's share of the proceeds from postage stamp sales.  Shell corporations were created specifically for the purpose of transferring the funds to the Cook Islands Party.In March 1978, the Cook Islands Party won the general election as a direct result of the votes cast by its supporters whose travel was paid for by Kenny International.  Sir Albert Henry remained in office as Premier.In July 1978, the election was contested and the Court disallowed the votes of the Cook Islands Party supporters whose travel had been subsidized as "unlawful votes tainted by bribery."  As a result, the Cook Islands Party lost its control of the Legislative Assembly and Sir Albert Henry was removed from office.  Kenny and Kenny International refused to pay the Government of the Cook Islands NZD 337,000, which was part of the Government's share of the proceeds of postage stamp sales.

The DOJ charged MEI and Mason with conspiring to violate the FCPA's anti-bribery provisions in connection with improper payments made to Dirk Ekkehard Zoeller, an official at the Militaerischer Abschirmenst, or the West German Military Intelligence Service (known by the acronym MAD), from April 1983 through October 1989.  The payments were made to secure a procurement contract from MAD for the development, production and servicing of a new technical security countermeasure ("TSCM") device called the MICRO-G, as well as related equipment and software. Under the U.S. Foreign Military Sales ("FMS") Program, the U.S. government loaned USD 5.5 million to the Republic of Niger between September 1981 and September 1983.  Under the FMS Program, the foreign government was permitted to work with a non-U.S. third party intermediary as long as the intermediary worked with a U.S.-based defense supplier.  A West German company, Dornier Reparaturwer GmbH ("Dornier"), signed a contract with the Niger government to perform maintenance on aircraft in February 1983.  The Niger Air Force, the Escardrille Nationale Nigerienne ("ENN"), however, could not come up with the required funds.  Not wanting to loose this potential business, Dornier established a relationship with NAPCO so that the Niger government could tap into the FMS funds.  From 1983-1987, the U.S. government approved three purchase orders worth approximately USD 3.2 million for aircraft parts for two airplanes owned by the Niger Air Force.  During the course of their relationship with the government of Niger, NAPCO's primary contacts were Tahirou Barke Doka, a Niger official serving as a Counselor in their Washington, D.C. embassy, and Captain Ali Tiemogo, the Chief of Maintenance for the Niger Air Force.The first contract, approved in December 1983, was worth USD 681,000.  In order to facilitate this order, NAPCO paid approximately USD 39,000 in bribes to Barke and Tiemogo through a fictitious sales agent, known as "E. Dave," with a bank account in Minnesota which was controlled by Barke.   The second contract, agreed upon in August 1984, was worth USD 1,000,000.  NAPCO ended its "relationship" with E. Dave at this time and employed a different "sales agent," the brother-in-law of Tiemogo, Amadou Mailele.  For the duration of the contract, at total of USD 49,000 in payments were made to Mailele and deposited in a Paris bank account.  In September 1985, NAPCO also offered to pay USD 2,028 to Barke for airline tickets on his honeymoon.  The third contract, worth approximately USD 1.5 million, was negotiated in August 1984.  The parties changed the "sales agent" again, this time to Fatouma Mailele Boube, the sister-in-law of Captain Tiemogo.  For her "services" she received USD 40,000 in payments from NAPCO, which were also wired to a bank account in Paris.Under FMS regulations, NAPCO was required to provide certain certifications relating to its contracts, agents, and various financial information in order for the funds to be issued.  From 1983-1987, NAPCO falsified documents submitted to the Defense Security Assistance Agency in order to conceal the improper payments it had made to Niger officials and/or their family members.  Furthermore, NAPCO filed inaccurate tax returns with the IRS in order to deduct the "commissions."NAPCO's representative throughout the incidents described above was Richard Liebo, Vice President for NAPCO's Aerospace Division.  The DOJ brought separate charges against both NAPCO and Liebo for violations of the FCPA in connection with the FMS sales to Niger.

From 1997 until 1999, Viktor Kozeny, Frederic Bourke, Jr., David Pinkerton, Hans Bodmer, Clayton Lewis, Thomas Farrell and others allegedly conspired to pay millions of dollars to Azeri officials in order to win an auction to gain control over the State Oil Company of the Azerbaijan Republic ("SOCAR").   The bribes were offered in stock shares, cash and other gifts.  Viktor Kozeny, Bourke's friend and neighbor in Aspen, Colorado, was allegedly the mastermind behind the conspiracy.  Kozeny created several companies, including Oily Rock Ltd. ("Oily Rock") and Minaret Group Ltd. ("Minaret") which he used to purchase vouchers and options in order to bid on shares of SOCAR.  Kozeny then allegedly agreed to transfer two-thirds of the vouchers and options to Azeri government officials and give them two-thirds of any profits Oily Rock realized from SOCAR's privatization. In addition, Kozeny allegedly paid more than USD 11 million to Azeri officials either through wire transfers to bank accounts held for their benefit or by hand delivering cash.  The indictment also lists gifts of jewelry and other luxury items as well as travel by Azeri officials to New York City in order to receive medical treatment as items of value given to senior Azeri officials under the scheme. Bourke, one of a number of investors, invested USD 8 million in Oily Rock. According to the government, he knew Kozeny was bribing Azeri government officials in order to win the bid for SOCAR.  Other investors included Omega Advisors, Inc., owned by Clayton Lewis; American International Group ("AIG"); and a number of Bourke's family and friends.  The Azeri government never privatized SOCAR and Oily Rock's investors lost their money.

During 1989, Mr. Gurin, president of AEA Aircraft Recovery, allegedly made improper payments to Dominican officials in connection with his attempt to recover a Piper Navajo aircraft seized by the government of the Dominican Republic.  Mr. Gurin employed several agents (namely Pou, Duran and Guasch) to make the payments  and secure the aircraft's release.  Throughout 1989, Mr. Gurin allegedly met several times with Mr. Pou to discuss arrangements to obtain the aircraft's release.  After conversations with other individuals involved in the scheme, Mr. Gurin allegedly approved a USD 5,000 check for distribution among Dominican military officials, which Mr. Pou personally delivered. After this initial payment, Mr. Duran allegedly consented to the establishment of an escrow account in his name to more easily facilitate the distribution of further payments.  In September 1989, Mr. Gurin allegedly gave Mr. Guasch USD 990 to bribe additional government officials.  Ultimately, Mr. Gurin, through the intermediaries listed above, allegedly paid approximately USD 20,000 in bribes to secure the release of the aircraft.

From 2001 until 2002, ACL allegedly made multiple payments to Egyptian officials through its Egyptian agent in order to obtain a contract for services and assistance to the Egyptian Air Force.  In October 1999, ACL received a sole source contract under the U.S. Foreign Military Sales ("FMS") Program to build a depot for F-16 combat aircraft for the Egyptian Air Force, and to provide, operate and train Egyptian labor to use the testing equipment installed in the depot. In the following years, ACL received a number of add-on contracts and contract modifications, including the Contract Engineering Technical Services (‰ÛÏCETS‰Ûù) contract.  These contracts generated approximately $64 million in revenue and $8.6 million in profit from 1999 until 2004, or one-third of ACL‰Ûªs gross revenue for that period. According to the SEC complaint, in 1996, Thomas Wurzel, ACL‰Ûªs president, hired a retired Egyptian Air Force general to act as an agent to help move the F-16 depot project forward. The consultant began receiving a monthly fee of $4,000. The company allegedly did not conduct any due diligence on the consultant until March 1998, when his consulting fee was increased to $20,000 per month. The consultant‰Ûªs company allegedly continued to receive payment from ACL even after the contract was awarded in 1999, in order to help the company obtain additional business related to the F-16 depot.  In addition to assisting ACL win new business, the Egyptian agent began acting as a labor contractor in 2000 to coordinate the labor needed for the project.  He was reimbursed for these services after submitting monthly invoices, which ranged from $4,300 to $11,000 per month. This contract was separate from the consulting contract. By mid-2001, the agent‰Ûªs contract had expired and was not renewed because ACL had satisfied its obligations; however, the agent continued to receive a number of payments from ACL because Wurzel had allegedly agreed to continue paying the consulting fee.  During early 2001, ACL began working toward winning the CETS contract, which involved providing personnel to provide technical assistance at the Air Force base where the depot was being constructed. The Egyptian agent assisted ACL with winning this contract. Months before the CETS contract was awarded, the agent allegedly sent emails to Wurzel stating that it was important ‰ÛÏto start giving motivation‰Ûù and requesting funds in order to ‰ÛÏsecure team loyalty.‰Ûù  According to the SEC complaint, the agent requested money that was separate from the funds he received under the labor support contract in January 2002 and April 2002. ACL paid the agent, but deducted these payments from his labor support contract.  ACL was awarded the CETS contract on April 30, 2002. ACL allegedly continued making payments to the agent after it received the CETS contract in order to win additional follow-up contracts.  According to SEC documents, the agent specifically requested that these funds not be deducted from his labor support contract. One such payment was made by using an invoice for an advance payment of rental equipment.  ACL was awarded five additional CETS contracts between 2002 and 2004. In January 2004, Wurzel traveled to Egypt and met with the agent during the trip.  While he was there, Wurzel allegedly agreed that ACL would forgive $100,000 of debt the agent owed to ACL as a result of an advance payment the agent received. Under Wurzel‰Ûªs plan, the agent would submit fake invoices to make it appear that the consultant had repaid the money. On December 18, 2007, Textron Inc. acquired UIC.

Young & Rubicam and its employees conspired to bribe Eric Abrahams, Jamaica's Minister of Tourism and Information, in order to obtain an advertising contract with the Jamaica Tourist Board.  In the early 1980s, Arnold Foote, a Jamaican national, and Robert Lowell, a U.S. citizen with connections in Jamaica, allegedly approached Young & Rubicam indicating that they were consultants to the Jamaican government and claiming to be able to help the company win contracts with the government, if they bribed Eric Abrahams.  The bribe was to be funneled through a company called Ad Ventures that the consultants established in the Cayman Islands. The consultants apparently never bribed Abrahams, but instead kept the payment.

IranIn the 29 May 2013 Deferred Prosecution Agreement between the U.S. Department of Justice ("DOJ") and Total, it was alleged that Total and its wholly owned subsidiary Total International made improper payments totaling approximately USD 60 million from 1995 to 2004. The alleged bribery scheme involved an Iranian official who was the chairman of an engineering company substantially owned and controlled by Iran, and was also the head of a wholly owned subsidiary of the National Iranian Oil Company, which is Iran's state-owned oil company. The Iranian official allegedly helped Total win over USD 1 billion in business from the Sirri A and E oil and gas fields and the South Pars gas field in exchange for approximately USD 60 million in payments to intermediaries designated by the Iranian official. The DOJ and SEC also alleged that these payments were not properly recorded in the Company's books and records and that they violated the FCPA's internal controls provisions.LibyaAlso, the Company noted in its 26 March 2012 SEC Form 20-F that the SEC has sent Total "a formal request for information related to their operations in Libya." IraqThe Oil-for-Food Program was established by the United Nations ("UN") to enable Iraq to sell its oil for humanitarian purposes, in the context of an extensive international sanctions regime. The Oil-for-Food Program mandated that the proceeds of oil sales be deposited in a UN bank account and that those proceeds be used by the Iraqi government only to purchase humanitarian goods and services, such as food and medicine, approved by the UN. Beginning in 2000, the former Iraqi government began requiring companies wishing to sell humanitarian goods to government ministries to pay a kickback, often mischaracterized as an "after sales services fee," to the government in order to be granted a contract. The amount of that fee was usually 10 percent of the contract price. Such payments were not permitted under the Oil-for-Food Program or other sanction regimes then in place.In its Form 20-F submission to the U.S. Securities & Exchange Commission ("SEC") on 26 March 2012, Total said that "certain current or former Group employees were placed under formal criminal investigation [in France] for possible charges as accessories to the misappropriation of corporate assets and as accessories to the corruption of foreign public agents." The Company also said that it "believes that its activities related to the Oil-for-Food program have been in compliance with thisprogram."ItalyOn 17 December 2008, the Financial Times reported that Italian police had arrested three employees of Total as a result of allegations of bribery involving the Tempa Rossa oilfield concession (also referred to as the Gorgoglione concession) in southern Italy. The Financial Times cited Italian media sources as saying that Italian authorities were investigating Total Italia for "the alleged corruption of local politicians who secured land in the concession at below market prices." The alleged value of the corrupt payments is EUR 15 million. The story reported that authorities have arrested or are investigating multiple politicians and businessmen, including a member of the Italian Parliament (Salvatore Margiotta) who allegedly requested a bribe from an intermediary of Total. In a 16 December 2008 story, Agence-France Press reported that Salvatore was one of 15 individuals named in the scandal, and that he requested approximately EUR 200,000 for his approval of the concession.

Radiola was awarded two United Nations ("U.N.") contracts in 2005-2006 to install runway lighting at the Kadugli airport in Sudan.  In May 2006, after the contract was completed, the U.N. attempted to block payment to Radiola, apparently based on rumors that the company had engaged in improprieties with U.N. staff at the Sudanese mission.On 18 December 2006, without a formal investigation or presentation of the allegations to Radiola, the company received a letter from the U.N. Procurement Division stating that the company had been removed from the U.N. vendor database based on "confirmed inappropriate relationships between Radiola and a U.N. official."  Radiola sought advice and explanation from the U.N. regarding the circumstances surrounding the allegations and the delisting, but received no response.   The company soon learned that it had been placed on the U.N. "blacklist."According to a story on 10 February 2008 in the Washington Post, Radiola allegedly participated in the drafting of a contract for runway light installation at the Kadugli airport in Sudan that the company ultimately won. According to the story, Radiola  "also sponsored a New Zealand visa application for the official's wife and pledged to cover any financial liabilities she might incur while in the country." The Washington Post reported that Radiola denied the allegations regarding the contract, but "acknowledged that it violated U.N. rules by sponsoring the visa . . . 'In hindsight it was inappropriate we should not have done it,' said Brent Albiston, Radiola's managing director. 'But absolutely no money passed hands.'"The U.N. referred the allegations to the New Zealand Police who then referred it to the Serious Fraud Office ("SFO").  The SFO investigated that matter, including conducting interviews with Radiola officers, and ultimately determined that there was no evidence of fraud or corruption on the part of Radiola or its Executive Director.

ABB voluntarily disclosed the payments to the DOJ and SEC in 2003, after the conduct was discovered during pre-merger due diligence. A group of investors was negotiating a deal with ABB to purchase its oil, gas and petrochemical division, which included the Vetco group of companies. In addition to requiring that ABB voluntarily disclose the conduct, the investors requested an Opinion Procedure Release from the DOJ, asking whether they could face successor liability for the conduct if they proceeded with the acquisition. According to Opinion Procedure Release 04-02, the investors and ABB undertook an extensive FCPA review of the upstream oil business for the previous five years. They each engaged independent auditors and counsel to review and analyze the information.  The FCPA review involved over 115 lawyers and 44,700 man-hours across 21 countries.  The investors and ABB turned over all of the information uncovered by the investigation to the DOJ and SEC. The investors also agreed to take remedial action, including implementing a robust FCPA compliance program and investigating the companies' conduct in other countries, to ensure that such payments would not continue in the future. Based on the representations made in Opinion Procedure Release 04-02, the DOJ agreed not to take any enforcement action against the investors for the conduct after closing. The investors did not comply with the representations made in the Opinion Procure Release and improper payments continued until 2007. It is believed that GE discovered the subsequent payments that led to the Vetco companies' second settlement during its own pre-merger due diligence to acquire the companies.  GE completed the acquisition in 2007, after the Vetco companies' settlement with the government, and assumed responsibility for maintaining the compliance monitor and ensuring that the Vetco companies complied with the terms of the settlement agreement.

ARGENTINAThe Argentine tax law required that all payments made to doctors be reported.  In order to conceal Biomet's payment of about 15-20% of its sales of medical devices to publicly owned hospitals, the company used fake invoices from the doctors, charging for professional services which in fact were not rendered.  These payments were recorded as "consulting fees" or "commissions."  In 2000, the tax law changed, and no untaxed payments to doctors were allowed, so Biomet began recording the payments as "royalties" or "other sales and marketing."  Biomet executives and auditors allegedly were aware of this practice, and took no steps to check the transactions.   In February 2006, Biomet's Latin America Auditor sent an internal report to the Senior Vice President, the Operations Manager, and other executives and managers, stating that allegations concerning "fraudulent product registration certificates, bribery of customs officials" were being investigated by Biomet, and that it had been determined "that certificates were fraudulent and bribes were made."In November 2006, the Latin America Auditor recommended that payments to the doctors  that were labeled "commission expenses" on the company records should be changed to "royalties." And even after the Company received a letter from the SEC regarding payments in other jurisdictions, it continued to make improper payments to surgeons in Argentina and reflect the 15-20% commissions in its accounting records.  However, in August 2008 the Company distributed new compliance guidelines, and this precipitated a suspension of all sales in Argentina.BRAZILBiomet sold its devices in Brazil through Biomet International, which engaged a distributor ("Brazilian Distributor") to pay bribes to physicians employed by public hospitals, as an inducement for them to buy Biomet medical implants.  At least as early as 2001, Biomet allegedly knew of these payments.  In February 2002, for example, the Director of Internal Audit stated in a memorandum to Biomet's Senior Vice President and Operations Manager: "Brazilian Distributor makes payments to surgeons that may be considered as a kickback.  These payments are made in cash that allows the surgeon to receive income tax free . . . The accounting entry is to increase a prepaid expense account.  In the consolidated financials sent to Biomet, these payments were reclassified to expense in the income statement."  In April 2008, Biomet had accountants and outside counsel perform due diligence on Brazilian Distributor, in anticipation of Biomet's purchase of the latter.  The due diligence revealed "cash payments to doctors and debit card purchases on behalf of doctors that raised red flags of bribery."  Biomet terminated its relationship with Brazilian Distributor, and temporarily ceased selling its products on the Brazilian market.  The Company wrote off USD 4.2 million in accounts receivable owed to it by the distributor.According to a Form 8-K filed by Biomet on 17 March 2015, Biomet became aware of other alleged improprieties in it's Brazil operations in October 2013. CHINABiomet sold its medical devices in China through subsidiaries Biomet China and Scandimed.  They used the Chinese Distributor to pay bribes to doctors employed in publicly owned hospitals, beginning at least in 2001.  The Chinese Distributor called the bribe payments "rebates" of 10-15%.  In February 2001, Scandimed wrote to Biomet's president of International Operations in Indiana, as well as Biomet employees in the UK that "as we understand it, giving commission [sic] or gifts of various kinds to surgeons is common in China," eliciting a response about sales margins from the President of International Operations.  The benefits conferred upon doctors in China included travel, as evidenced in a May 2001 email from Chinese Distributor to Biomet's  Associate Regional Manager explaining how to overcome objections by a particular doctor "[Doctor] will become the most loyal customer of Biomet if we send him to Switzerland."  Another email mentioned that doctor was the head of a department in a public hospital in Shanghai, and that "many key surgeons in Shanghai are buddies of his...Dinner has been set for the evening of the 24th...But dinner aside, I've got to send him to Switzerland to visit his daughter."  Some emails contain clear explanations of how the commissions were paid, as in one from the Chinese Distributor to the Associate Regional Manager, dated 21 April 2002:  "When we say 'Surgeon Rebate included,' it means the invoice price includes a predetermined percentage for the surgeon.  For example, a vendor invoices the hospital for a set of plate & screws at RMB 3,000.00.  The vendor will have to deliver RMB 750.00 (25% in this case) in cash to the surgeon upon completion of surgery [sic]."  Emails from 2005 indicate that payments made to doctors in connection with clinical trials were recorded in the Company's books as "entertainment," and that doctors conducting clinical trials are paid a 10-15% "consulting fee." In 2006, Biomet elected to cut the Chinese Distributor out of its Chinese operations, and to use Biomet sales staff instead.  In October 2007, the Company paid for 20 Chinese surgeons to fly to Barcelona and Valencia for training, with "a substantial portion of the trip" devoted to sightseeing and entertainment.  In the same month, a product manager in Biomet China discussed ways to evade anti-corruption measures that had been taken by the Chinese government, noting "Obviously, China government [sic] doesn't have ability to forbid the corruption from hospitals & surgeons."  The product manager suggested falsifying invoices, among other methods.MEXICOAccording to a Form 8-K filed by Biomet on 3 July 2014, Biomet became aware of alleged improprieties in it's Mexico operations in October 2013.

In January 2009, the U.S. Department of State said it would not renew its security contract with Blackwater, which was due to run out in May 2009, because the Iraqi government had revoked the company's license to operate in the country. According to the indictment, the defendants purchased over 200 short barrels to install into long-barreled rifles for use in Iraq and Afghanistan. They also allegedly gave several guns to Jordanian officials in an attempt to secure a lucrative contract with the Jordanian government, later falsifying forms submitted to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives.

We are cooperating with the SEC and the DOJ in this investigation."The statement was repeated in the Company's SEC Form 10-K Annual Report for 2011 filed on 24 February 2012. On 20 December 2012, the SEC filed a complaint in which the following allegations are made.Poland AllegationsBeginning in 2000, the Company's wholly-owned  subsidiary in Poland ("Lilly-Poland") negotiated contracts with various regional public health authorities, including the Silesian Health Fund, to supply public health facilities with specific pharmaceuticals from a list of approved products.  Gemzar, a cancer drug, became one of the approved products after Lilly-Poland's manager agreed to contribute to the Chudow Foundation, a charitable organization devoted to restoring castles in Silesia.  The Chudow Foundation was founded by and administered by the Director of the Silesian Health Fund.  Lilly-Poland eventually paid about USD 39,000 to the Chudow Foundation,in eight payments, which were falsely recorded in the requesting documentation as "indirect support of educational efforts [of the Silesia Health Fund]."   The Complaint offers evidence that the payments were intended for the improper purpose of inducing the director of the Health Fund to agree to the purchase of Gemzar, and alleges that Lilly-Poland's Medical Grant Committee approved the payments to Chudow without analyzing the circumstances, such as the high-level government health official's involvement in both the Chudow Foundation and the Gemzar negotiations, and without questioning the proximity between the time of payment to the foundation and the date of the meeting at which the Company's drug was approved for purchase by the Health Fund, or the fact that the written justifications given for the payments were different, although the recipient was the same.  (In fact, the Chudow Foundation was alleged to be the recipient of improper payments by Schering Plough during approximately the same period; that company settled FCPA charges in 2004 without admitting or denying the allegations.)Russia AllegationsThe SEC's complaint alleges that the Company's wholly-owned subsidiary in Russia, Lilly-Vostok, entered into 96 "marketing" or "service" agreements with 42 third-parties selected by government officials.  The third-parties  received a percentage of drug sales or a flat fee in bank accounts located outside of Russia.  The agreements listed services such as "immediate customs clearance" or "immediate delivery," "obtaining payment for the sales transaction," "promotion of products," or "marketing research."  Lilly-Vostok is alleged to have received no actual services pursuant to these contracts, and its employees are alleged to have deemed the payments as necessary for obtaining business with government entities.   Reports were sent to the Company's management in 1997 and 1999 which raised concerns about the contracts and recommended that internal controls be modified.  According to the complaint, despite these warning signs the Company did not limit the use of such agreements or make any effort to ensure that money was not being channeled to foreign officials by means of the agreements.  For example, in 2003 Lilly-Vostok paid  as much as 30% of sales to entities in Cyprus  that were owned and controlled by a member of the Russian Parliament who, according to the complaint, "exercised considerable influence over government decisions relating to the pharmaceutical industry in Russia."  Ultimately, Lilly-Vostok paid the Cypriot entities over USD 5.2 million.  Similar transactions involving a British Virgin Islands company resulted in Lilly-Vostok making 65 payments totaling USD 2 million that were channeled to the Director General of a Russian government entity.  These transactions continued until 2005.  China AllegationsSales representatives  and supervisors employed by the Company's wholly-owned subsidiary in China, "Lilly-China," allegedly submitted false expense reports between 2006 and 2009, and used the cash generated by the false reports to buy gifts such as wine and jewelery, and to pay for entertainment, meals and cosmetics for government-employed physicians.  The gifts are alleged to have been intended to induce doctors to prescribe the Company's products.Brazil AllegationsIn 2007, the Company's Brazilian subsidiary ("Lilly-Brazil")  gave unusually large discounts to a pharmaceutical distributor.  The Company's pricing committee approved the discounts without adequate verification of the circumstances.  Sales of the highly discounted drugs totaled approximately USD 1.2 million.  The complaint alleges that the distributor used 6% of the purchase price to bribe government officials so that the public health facilities would purchase the Company's product.
